title: After loss to Warren, Republican John Deaton announces another run for Senate
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: John Deaton, a Marine veteran and lawyer, announces run for Senator Ed Markey's seat in 2026.
Deaton, a cryptocurrency advocate, previously ran against Elizabeth Warren and highlights his outsider status and military service.
Markey, seeking another term, faces primary challenge from Rep. Seth Moulton, with Rep. Ayanna Pressley considering a run.

title: What will the Red Sox target this offseason? Craig Breslow maps out Boston’s priorities.
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Red Sox seek to acquire a top starting pitcher to pair with Garrett Crochet for the 2026 season.
Boston targets power hitters via free agency to bolster lineup, considering players like Kyle Schwarber and Pete Alonso.
Red Sox emphasize maintaining competitiveness while planning for future roster improvements through trades and free agency.

title: Zdeno Chara’s 10 most memorable moments with the Bruins
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Zdeno Chara named to the Hockey Hall of Fame, celebrated for his impact as a Bruins captain and dominant defenseman.
Chara signed with the Boston Bruins in 2006, leading to a successful era with three Stanley Cup Finals appearances.
Chara set the NHL record for the hardest shot at 108.8 mph and won the Norris Trophy in 2009.

title: Bill Belichick reflects on ‘learning curve’ during first season coaching college football
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Bill Belichick reflects on his first season as UNC's head coach, facing a learning curve in college football.
UNC is 4-5 in the ACC standings, needing two more wins to match last season's total of six.
Belichick acknowledged earlier missteps and the team's improvement following back-to-back wins against Syracuse and Stanford.

title: Patriots have 15 players land on injury report, but get some good news
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots report 15 players on injury list ahead of Thursday's game against the Jets after Sunday's win over Tampa.
Kayshon Boutte and Rhamondre Stevenson were limited on Monday, showing signs of recovery from hamstring and toe injuries.
Tight end Austin Hooper missed Monday's practice due to concussion, affecting Patriots' preparation during shortened week.

title: Georgia man allegedly stole millions in unclaimed Mass. property
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Shaka Stayman, 44, from Atlanta, charged with stealing millions in unclaimed Massachusetts property using falsified documents.
Stayman allegedly cashed $1.1 million in checks and attempted to claim an additional $2.2 million.
He is held on $2 million bail as he awaits sentencing for unrelated federal charges in Alabama.

title: TreVeyon Henderson explained why he looked at the sideline during key TD run
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: TreVeyon Henderson considered clock management during a key Patriots touchdown run, looking to the sideline for guidance.
Henderson's performance included over 100 yards and multiple touchdowns, highlighting his increased role with key players injured.
Patriots coach Mike Vrabel praised the blocking efforts that allowed Henderson to achieve significant gains during the game.

title: Mason Lohrei is latest Bruins player to respond from a Marco Sturm benching
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Mason Lohrei responded with a strong performance after being benched for five games, helping the Bruins defeat Toronto 5-3.
Lohrei recorded two assists in Saturday's game, stepping in for Charlie McAvoy, who was out due to a personal matter.
Coach Marco Sturm's benching strategy has seen multiple Bruins, including Lohrei, improve performances after being healthy scratches.

title: Petitioners gathering signatures to repeal legal marijuana accused of misleading voters
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Petitioners seeking to repeal recreational marijuana in Massachusetts face accusations of misleading voters about the petition's content.
Complaints suggest signature gatherers misrepresented the initiative, prompting fraud allegations from the Massachusetts Cannabis Business Association.
State officials remind voters to read petitions before signing as complaints about misinformation in signature collection arise.

title: Massachusetts state payroll hits $9B in 2025 — UMass system dominates
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Massachusetts state payroll reached $9.19 billion in 2025, a decrease from $10.26 billion the previous year.
All top 15 highest-paid Massachusetts state employees in 2025 were from the University of Massachusetts system.
UMass Men's Basketball Head Coach Frank Martin was the highest-paid state employee, earning $1,955,216.
